Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of deaths in Puerto Rico caused by the hurricanes, stating that 3,000 people "did not die" when the official estimate is lower.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the death toll estimate of 3,000 was determined by experts on disaster response, not by Democrats.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in the death toll estimate was a deliberate effort by Democrats to make President Trump look bad, without providing sufficient evidence to support this assumption.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the statement that the death toll estimate was "done by Democrats."
Falters at times: The claim falters by ignoring the basic facts about the reality faced by Puerto Ricans after the hurricanes and miscasting the estimate as a Democratic effort.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the increase in the death toll estimate, such as the inclusion of indirect deaths caused by the hurricanes.
Understate: The claim understates the actual number of deaths in Puerto Rico by suggesting that the count was only 6 to 18 deaths when President Trump left the island after the storm.
